instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-3437: What is 820-3437? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.LP8550: What is LP8550? This is an LED driver responsible for creating the backlight on the LCD screen of Macbooks from 2011 through 2015.
definitions.SMC_LID: What is SMC_LID? SMC_LID tells the machine the system is open when it is 3.3v to 3.4v, and closed when it is low such as 0v-0.6v. When this signal is low, the machine may go to sleep or have no backlight. .

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> powers on, no backlight and no green light
threads.message: I have a water damaged <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> that powers on, there is backlight for a sec then it turns off and also there is no green light. I have replaced <CHIP>LP8550</CHIP> already and also ran a trace from ball 5 on <CHIP>LP7701</CHIP> to pin 1 of <CAPACITOR>C7796</CAPACITOR> because I thought I had a bad feedback trace. (Any suggestions on an easier way to measure for a bad trace besides continunity mode from eah side of the board would be great).  After that I still have backlight for only a sec and I am still getting 8.5V on backlight circuit.  Please help!!

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> powers on, no backlight and no green light
threads.message: If you have backlight for a second it could be because of the <SIGNAL>SMC_LID</SIGNAL> signal is pulled down.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> powers on, no backlight and no green light
threads.message: Flatcable, IO board or connectors in that order.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> powers on, no backlight and no green light
threads.message: How does <SIGNAL>SMC_LID</SIGNAL> get pulled down?? OR how do I fix this??

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> powers on, no backlight and no green light
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> powers on, no backlight and no green light
threads.message:
It normally gets pulled down when you close the lid. The sensor is in the lio board thats why duke says you should try with another one. But if thats not the case then in more rare situations it could also be the trackpad (or ipd connector/cable) or SMC or <CAPACITOR>C4835</CAPACITOR>.

But start by measuring <SIGNAL>SMC_LID</SIGNAL> to check if its high or low to see if it is because of this or not.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> powers on, no backlight and no green light
threads.message: Could be crap in the touchpad connector also or crap in the IO board connector. I bet <SIGNAL>SMC_LID</SIGNAL> is pulled low and that is the only place that goes.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> powers on, no backlight and no green light
threads.message:
Last time I had this issue, backlight for a split second, <SIGNAL>SMC_LID</SIGNAL> was between the high and low levels (2.1v), SMC itself was shorting the signal. (Yes the worse case)
My trackpad and keyboard were not properly working, except with external monitor plugged in.
SMC replacement solved the issue.
